IRenderer

Defines our basic renderer. IRenderer handles all rendering commands.  It is generally expected that this object is running on its own thread.

Header

Rendering/Caustic/IRenderer.h

Functions

virtual CComPtr<ID3D11Device> GetDevice() = 0
Returns

virtual void Setup(
HWND hwnd,
std::wstring &shaderFolder,
bool createDebugDevice
) = 0

Initializes the renderer. Applications need to call this method at startup.

Parameters

window to bind renderer to

shaderFolder

path to shader folder

createDebugDevice
bool

True if application wants the debug D3D device. False otherwise.

DrawMesh
virtual void DrawMesh(
IRenderSubMesh *pMesh,
IMaterialAttrib *pMaterial,
ITexture *pTexture,
IShader *pShader,
DirectX::XMMATRIX &mat
) = 0

Renders a mesh by adding it to the Renderable list that is drawn each time a frame is rendered

TODO: This method needs to be refactored. There is no point in sending in both a pMaterial and a pTexture (the material already should define the diffuse texture). Also, we should pass in both a front and back face material

Parameters
pMesh
IRenderSubMesh*

mesh to render

pMaterial
IMaterialAttrib*

material for front faces

pTexture
ITexture*

texture for diffuse component

pShader
IShader*

shader to use to draw mesh

mat
DirectX::XMMATRIX&

matrix to transform mesh by
